channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: DealBook: Goldman Deal Threatens Danish Government
item.description: When Denmark gave the company approval to buy a stake in its state utility, the Socialist People’s Party withdrew its ministers from the country’s governing coalition.
item.dc:creator: By DANNY HAKIM
item.media:description: Prime Minister Helle Thorning-Schmidt said on Thursday that she would form a new government after some ministers quit.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Malaysian Admiral Plays Down Talk of Chinese Naval Incursion
item.description: The top Malaysian naval commander has taken umbrage at reports that Chinese ships entered into disputed waters claimed by Malaysia.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: A pointer on a map in a Chinese passport shows disputed islands in the South China Sea.

item.title: The Lede: Scarlett Johansson Chooses SodaStream Over Oxfam After Dispute About West Bank Factory
item.description: Forced to choose, Scarlett Johansson decided to end her charitable work on behalf of Oxfam, which opposes trade with Israeli settlements, and continue as a paid “brand ambassador” for SodaStream, which makes products in the occupied West Bank.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: India Ink: A Conversation with: Filmmaker Gyan Correa
item.description: The writer and director of “The Good Road” spoke with India Ink about why he made the film about travelers along a major highway and why he based it in the Rann of Kutch in Gujarat.
item.dc:creator: By SHIRAZ SIDHVA
item.media:description: Gyan Correa, writer and director of the film "The Good Road."

item.title: White House Urges China to Act on Journalists’ Visas
item.description: The statement was the latest public effort on behalf of reporters for Bloomberg and The New York Times thwarted in their work by visa delays.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL D. SHEAR

item.title: ‘Framework’ for Talks on Mideast in Progress
item.description: The Obama administration, seeking to jump-start negotiations between Israelis and Palestinians, hopes to complete an accord that would set terms for final talks, a State Department official said.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER

item.title: N.S.A. Choice Is Navy Expert on Cyberwar
item.description: Vice Adm. Michael S. Rogers, a cryptologist by training, will become the public face of the N.S.A. at a moment that it is caught in the cross hairs of a roiling debate.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER and THOM SHANKER
item.media:credit: Nathan L. Guimont/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Vice Adm. Michael S. Rogers in 2012.

item.title: Scarlett Johansson and Oxfam, Torn Apart by Israeli Company Deal
item.description: The actress’s endorsement of a company with a factory in an area of the West Bank that Palestinians envision as part of a future independent state has created an international political storm.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: SodaStream has a factory in a West Bank settlement.

item.title: Delay in Chemical Arms Pledge Criticized
item.description: The United States sharply criticized Syria for what it called serious and unjustifiable delays in the export of the Syrian chemical weapons stockpile.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE and NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel, right, met with Polish defense minister Tomasz Siemoniak, left, on Thursday.

item.title: Egypt Tries to Reassure Journalists From Abroad
item.description: The government told foreign correspondents that they are free to work in Egypt after prosecutors accused 20 journalists for Al Jazeera television of conspiring with the Muslim Brotherhood.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: World Briefing: Bangladesh: 14 Sentenced to Die for Smuggling Arms
item.description: The leader of the main Islamist opposition party was among 14 people convicted and sentenced to death for smuggling weapons to a rebel group in India nearly a decade ago.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Panama: 32 of 35 Detained North Koreans to Be Freed
item.description: The crew members of a North Korean freighter have been held since July, when Soviet-era jets, engines and antiaircraft missiles from Cuba were found on board.
item.dc:creator: By PAULINA VILLEGAS

item.title: Talks Stall as President of Ukraine Calls in Sick
item.description: Viktor F. Yanukovych, saddled by respiratory issues, went on leave even as talks remained unsettled and the repeal of new curbs on speech and assembly was yet to be signed into law.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: Protesters remained in Independence Square in Kiev on Thursday, as Ukraine’s president, Viktor F. Yanukovych, took a sick leave of unknown length. Some skeptics questioned his motives.

item.title: World Briefing: Libya: Date Set for Vote to Select Constitutional Panel
item.description: Libya’s interim Parliament has set Feb. 20 as the date for a national election to choose a 50-member panel to draft the country’s constitution, Nouri Abusahmain, the body’s president, said.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Hong Kong Paper Ousts Top Editor, Stirring Concern
item.description: Ming Pao’s history as a serious, independent paper has given it outsize influence, but it might be the latest victim of the mainland’s effort to rein in the media here.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY and GERRY MULLANY
item.media:description: Protesters massed outside the Ming Pao newspaper offices Sunday to support its independence.

item.title: Obama and G.O.P. Facing Opposition to Trade Pacts
item.description: President Obama, supported by many Republicans and business groups, has met opposition from labor and many Democrats on his push for fast-track approval of trade deals with Pacific Rim nations and Europe.
item.dc:creator: By ANNIE LOWREY
item.media:description: Senator Harry Reid of Nevada said he did not support trade-promotion authority for the Obama administration. On Tuesday, President Obama pushed for two trade deals in his State of the Union address.

item.title: Amanda Knox Is Re-Convicted of Murder in Italy
item.description: Ms. Knox and her former boyfriend Raffaele Sollecito were found guilty of killing her roommate in 2007, a case that had already gone through three levels of judgment and produced mixed verdicts.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Its Great Lake Shriveled, Iran Confronts Crisis of Water Supply
item.description: President Hassan Rouhani has identified water as a national security issue, and nowhere is the crisis more pronounced than at Lake Urmia, once one of the largest salt lakes in the world.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:credit: Morteza Nikoubazl for The New York Times
item.media:description: An abandoned ship rusts in the mud on the south shore of Lake Urmia, where only 5 percent of the water remains, Iranian environmental officials say.

item.title: Syria Talks May Yield Little, but Give Cover to Those Defying Hard-Liners
item.description: Government supporters complained that the opposition delegation could not claim to represent all opponents, let alone all Syrians, while opposition activists said they would look weak if they failed to win concessions.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD and MOHAMMAD GHANNAM
item.media:description: Civilians in the embattled city of Aleppo on Thursday.

item.title: The Lede: Charge Sheet Against Al Jazeera Journalists in Egypt
item.description: A translation of the complete statement by Egyptian prosecutors charging 20 journalists working for Al Jazeera with joining a terrorist group and broadcasting false news.
item.dc:creator: By MAYY EL SHEIKH and ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: London Journal: Need the Best for Your Next Occasion? Call Westminster Palace
item.description: In a fund-raising effort, the authorities at Britain’s Parliament have decided to rent out some of its premises to keep the building in shape.
item.dc:creator: By KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: The authorities at Britain’s Parliament have decided to rent out some of its premises to keep the 19th-century building in shape.

item.title: Continuing Unrest Could Undermine Thailand’s Economy
item.description: Companies are reconsidering investments in light of the protests and political gridlock the economy has normally shrugged off in past years.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By BETTINA WASSENER

item.title: The Lede: Video From Snowden’s German TV Interview
item.description: In excerpts from an interview with German television, the former National Security Agency contractor Edward Snowden dismissed President Obama’s proposed reforms and threats to his life published in Buzzfeed.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: As Gaza Tunnels Closed, Hamas Lost Cash, Israeli Official Says
item.description: The Islamic militant group lost a major source of income because of an Egyptian clampdown on smuggling tunnels, an Israeli military official said.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: A variety of goods, including flour, fuel and building materials, had flowed into Gaza through the tunnels.

item.title: Letter From Europe: Atonement for Inventor of the AK-47
item.description: Before he died at age 94 in December, Mikhail T. Kalashnikov wrote to a priest saying, "my spiritual torment is unbearable."
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: A Somali boy with an assault rifle based on the AK-47 in Elasha Biyaha, near Mogadishu, in July 2012.
